segments.pli: Atha kho aññataro bhikkhu … pe … etadavoca:
segments.en: Then a mendicant went up to the Buddha … and asked him,

segments.pli: “atthi nu kho, bhante, eko dhammo yassa pahānā bhikkhuno avijjā pahīyati, vijjā uppajjatī”ti?
segments.en: “Sir, is there one thing such that by giving it up a mendicant gives up ignorance and gives rise to knowledge?”

segments.pli: “Atthi kho, bhikkhu, eko dhammo yassa pahānā bhikkhuno avijjā pahīyati, vijjā uppajjatī”ti.
“Katamo pana, bhante, eko dhammo yassa pahānā bhikkhuno avijjā pahīyati, vijjā uppajjatī”ti?
“Avijjā kho, bhikkhu, eko dhammo yassa pahānā bhikkhuno avijjā pahīyati, vijjā uppajjatī”ti.
segments.en: “Ignorance is one thing such that by giving it up a mendicant gives up ignorance and gives rise to knowledge.”

segments.pli: “Kathaṃ pana, bhante, jānato, kathaṃ passato avijjā pahīyati, vijjā uppajjatī”ti?
segments.en: “But how does a mendicant know and see so as to give up ignorance and give rise to knowledge?”
When a mendicant has heard that
nothing is worth clinging on to,

segments.pli: So sabbaṃ dhammaṃ abhijānāti, sabbaṃ dhammaṃ abhiññāya sabbaṃ dhammaṃ parijānāti, sabbaṃ dhammaṃ pariññāya sabbanimittāni aññato passati, cakkhuṃ aññato passati, rūpe …
segments.en: they directly know all things. Directly knowing all things, they completely understand all things. Completely understanding all things, they see all signs as other. They see the eye, sights,

segments.pli: yampidaṃ cakkhusamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṃ sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā tampi aññato passati … pe …
segments.en: And they also see the pleasant, painful, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by eye contact as other. …

segments.pli: yampidaṃ manosamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṃ sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā tampi aññato passati.
segments.en: And they also see the pleasant, painful, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by mind contact as other.

segments.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhu, jānato evaṃ passato bhikkhuno avijjā pahīyati, vijjā uppajjatī”ti.
segments.en: That’s how a mendicant knows and sees so as to give up ignorance and give rise to knowledge.”

sections.title: Then a mendicant went up to the Buddha ……

suttaplex.blurb: Through giving up ignorance, knowledge arises. To do this, contemplate the six senses as impermanent. Then a mendicant truly understands, and sees everything differently.
